title.narrative: Gender Equity in Production Development and food Security in Pancasan

description.narrative: - Workshops on foliar and soil fertilizers - Workshops on cocoa agro-forestry management for promoters - Workshop on coffee agro-forestry management for promoters - Material and field training for grafting mature cocoa trees - Workshop for strengthening promoters in the nutritional value of food - Workshop for establishment of bio-intensive orchards - Participation of leaders in cooperative forum - Participation of women in national fairs to market crops and establish market relations. - Training for network of gender promoters

This project will directly benefit 409 heads of household in the municipality of Pancasan in contributing to increased food security through increased productivity of marketed crops (coffee, cocoa, corn, beans) for female and male farmers, diversification of farms to incorporate new food crops and marketable crops to diversify both food supply and income sources of female and male farmers, strengthening the capacity of the local cooperative to provide improved marketing and credit services to male and female farmers, and promoting greater information sharing and involvement in decision making with regards to household and farm management among male and female household members. This project will indirectly benefit 734 rural residents including family members and community members through increased availability of a greater diversity of food crops locally, diversification of the local economy into more than just coffee and cocoa, and improved incomes through collective marketing strategies. This project contributes to gender learning for ADDAC and LWR in 3 ways: 1. By assessing and incorporating into project design different needs and obstacles men and women face in participating in and benefiting from project activities given different work loads, access to resources and mobility. 2. By tracking indicators at the activity, output and outcome levels dis-aggregated by sex we will be able to monitor whether men and women are equally able to participate in and benefit from project activities and adjust implementation accordingly. 3. By carrying out a final evaluation to assess the gender equity contributions of this project as well as its contributions to household food security we will be able to learn from this experience about how to better incorporate gender equity into food security projects and how this contributes to household food security outcomes.
